title: 110_s3451
content: The Act may be cited as the "Strengthening Our Economy Through Small Business Innovation Act of 2008". The Senate recognizes the importance of small businesses in the nation's economy, highlighting their role in employment, innovation, technological advancement, and national interests. The SBIR and STTR programs are acknowledged for their contribution to developing new products and processes. The Senate acknowledges the importance of small businesses in the economy, emphasizing their role in employment, innovation, and national interests. The SBIR and STTR programs should be extended for transportation efficiencies and domestic security, with administrative costs covered by Federal departments and agencies. The Small Business Act is amended to extend the termination dates for the SBIR and STTR programs to 2022 and 2023 respectively. Additionally, there is an increase in the allocation of federal agency grants for these programs. The Small Business Act is amended to increase the budget allocations for the SBIR and STTR programs in fiscal years 2008 to 2011 and beyond. The Small Business Act is amended to increase budget allocations for the SBIR and STTR programs, with minimum percentages set for fiscal years 2009 to 2011 and beyond. SEC. 5 amends the Small Business Act to increase SBIR and STTR award levels significantly. SEC. 6 includes energy, security, transportation, and water-related research as topics deserving special consideration for SBIR research. Section 9(g)(3) of the Small Business Act is amended to include research priorities related to emerging renewable energy, energy efficiency, and renewable fuels technologies from reports issued by the National Academy of Sciences. The Federal Role in the National Program project includes reports from the Research and Innovative Technology Administration of the Department of Transportation, the National Academy of Sciences, and the Committee on Water System Security Research. The reports focus on transportation, infrastructure, water security, and public water distribution systems. Water Distribution Systems: Assessing and Reducing Risks' is mentioned in reports by the National Academy of Sciences and the Environmental Protection Agency. The Government Accountability Office also highlighted limitations in detecting hazardous releases and tracking radioactive materials in urban areas. The National Academy of Science reports on cybersecurity technologies to protect privacy. The Secretary of Defense will terminate the Airborne Laser program as per SEC. 7 OFFSET.
